Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 52188-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
October 2018 
 
 
 
 
 
Assessing Economic Corridor Development 
Potential Among Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, and 
Tajikistan 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Public Communications 
Policy 2011.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ABEC  –  Almaty−Bishkek Economic Corridor 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
CAREC  –  Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation 
CWRC  –  Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination Division 
    of Central and West Asia Department 
DMC  –  developing member country 
EAEU  –  Eurasian Economic Union 
ECD  –  economic corridor development 
RCI  −  regional cooperation and integration 
TA  −  technical assistance 
 
 
 
 
NOTE 
In this report, "$" refers to United States dollars. 
 
Vice-President  Wencai Zhang, Operations 1 
Director General  Werner Liepach, Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) 
Director                    Safdar Parvez, Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination 
Division, CWRD 
   
Team leader  Xinglan Hu, Senior Regional Cooperation Specialist, ERCD 
Team members  Esnerjames Fernandez, Programs Analyst, CWRD 
Kristian Rosbach, Economist (Regional Cooperation), CWRD 
Maria Cecilia Sison, Operations Assistant, CWRD 
Kiyoshi Taniguchi, Principal Economist, ERCD 
Guoliang Wu, Senior Regional Cooperation Specialist, CWRD 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the assessment of 
economic corridor development (ECD) potential among Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, and Tajikistan, 
with focus on major cities of Shymkent, Tashkent, and Khujand and surrounding oblasts of 
Turkestan, Tashkent, and Sughd. The TA was designed in response to demand from developing 
member countries (DMCs) under the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) 
Program to explore new ECDs to create business development opportunities, employment, and 
entrepreneurship, as ECD is an important element in the implementation of the CAREC 2030 
strategy.1 The TA builds on ongoing Almaty−Bishkek Economic Corridor (ABEC) work supported 
by the Asian Development Bank (ADB).2 The TA is aligned with ADB’s Operational Plan for 
Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2016–2020, which advocates ECD as effective means to 
enhance competitiveness in connected markets.3 The TA participating countries are also covered 
by the Belt and Road Initiative geography.4  
   
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Central Asia is undergoing an economic recovery and benefiting from positive regional 
dynamics  with  the  opening  of  Uzbekistan.  Under  the  new  circumstances,  Central  Asian 
countries—particularly Uzbekistan and neighboring Kazakhstan and Tajikistan—are keen to 
harness the potential of regional cooperation and integration (RCI) to promote growth, create jobs, 
and improve the quality of life of their citizens. Trade has been identified in these countries as an 
enabling driver in diversifying economies from a narrow-base (overreliance on natural resources) 
into a more broad-based and sustainable growth model, for enhanced export competitiveness. 
Further, the growing trend of regional and global production networks, value chains, and new 
technologies,  coupled  with  improved  information  and  communication  technology,  create 
necessary conditions for Central Asia and CAREC member countries to increase participation in 
regional and global trade. A CAREC Integrated Trade Agenda 2030 is being formulated to 
facilitate this process. 5  
 
3.  All these provide favorable conditions for Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, and Tajikistan to 
pursue cross-border ECD cooperation to increase trade integration. ECD works by exploiting the 
strong  growth  effects  of  spatial  economic  development  featured  by  scale  economies, 
agglomeration, diversification, and specialization of economic activities. ECD requires necessary 
physical conditions and seamless policy coordination to achieve desired effects. Showcased by 
successful ECDs in Asia—e.g., Malaysia’s five-ECD national development strategy and India’s 
Delhi−Mumbai Industrial Corridor for manufacturing and exports—as well as the ABEC pilot under 
CAREC, and considering the geographic contiguity for spatial planning and development, the 
Shymkent−Tashkent−Khujand cities and surrounding Turkestan−Tashkent−Sughd oblasts were 
identified as another possible ECD to be explored under CAREC. 6   
                                                
1  ADB. 2017. CAREC 2030: Connecting the Region for Shared and Sustainable Development. Manila. The trade, 
tourism, and economic corridor cluster is among the five operational clusters under CAREC 2030, which will help 
further develop the Almaty−Bishkek Economic Corridor and assess the potential of other corridors in the region.  
2  ADB. 2017. Technical Assistance for Almaty−Bishkek Economic Corridor Support. Manila. 
3 ADB. 2016. Operational Plan for Regional Cooperation and Integration, 2016–2020: Promoting Connectivity, 
Competitiveness, Regional Public Goods, and Collective Action for Asia and the Pacific. Manila.   
4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 8 October 2018. 
5  CAREC. 2018. CAREC Integrated Trade Agenda 2030, Regional Trade Group. Presentation for CAREC Senior 
Officials’ Meeting. Bangkok. 27−28 June.   
6  ADB. 2014. Operationalizing Economic Corridors in Central Asia: A Case Study of the Almaty−Bishkek Corridor. 
Manila (Box: Economic Corridor Development in Practice, p. 8). Shymkent is administratively a city of Republican 
significance of Kazakhstan, and is geographically under the Turkestan Oblast; Tashkent is administratively the capital

2 
 
4.  The Shymkent−Tashkent−Khujand cities and surrounding Turkestan−Tashkent−Sughd 
oblasts are within easy access of each other: 100 kilometers between Shymkent and Tashkent, 
and 160 kilometers between Tashkent and Khujand. These cities and oblasts host a relatively 
large population: roughly 9 million people or 15% of the total population of Central Asia are within 
the Turkestan−Tashkent−Sughd oblasts.7 They are also strategically connected to international 
markets: Shymkent is located in the international crossroads of Europe−East Asia (CAREC 
Corridor 1) and Russian Federation−Middle East and South Asia (CAREC Corridor 3), and 
Tashkent and Khujand are tourist centers. Moreover, the three cities and surrounding oblasts 
enjoy  a  level  of  economic  complementarity,  particularly  in  agriculture  and  food,  based  on 
nationwide  trade  data.  For  example,  Kazakhstan  exports  agri-food  and  meat  products  to 
Uzbekistan  and  Tajikistan  and  imports  vegetables  and  fruits  from  them.8  Another  clear 
complementarity is the cross-border labor mobility facilitated by the close historical, cultural, and 
linguistic ties among the three countries.    
   
5.  There are growing economic interactions among the three countries: mutual trade turnover 
between Uzbekistan and Tajikistan grew by 35% and amounted to $160 million for the first half of 
2018. However, policy coordination on spatial economic development is limited, including on 
development of economic and industrial clusters in the Shymkent−Tashkent−Khujand cities and 
surrounding oblasts. There is significant potential to harness increased economic opportunities—
for example, Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan agreed to increase trade to $5 billion by 2020 from the 
expected $3 billion in 2018—if policies to integrate manufacturing value chains and synergize 
economic and industrial clusters are well-coordinated among the three cities and surrounding 
oblasts.  
 
6.  Physical connectivity within the six CAREC corridors (Corridors 2 and 3 cover the three 
cities and oblasts) has been improved with major investment in road infrastructure in recent years 
(e.g.,  the  Shymkent-Tashkent  Road  Rehabilitation  Project  financed  by  ADB).  However, 
challenges still exist, especially at border-crossing points, including substandard physical facilities 
and uncoordinated procedures, which weaken cross-border trade flows. Moreover, trade policies 
and regulations, if harmonized—particularly among the member (Kazakhstan) and nonmembers 
(Uzbekistan and Tajikistan) of the Eurasian Economic Union (EAEU)—can reduce trade costs 
and lower additional costs for non-EAEU firms in complying with EAEU requirements.     
 
7.   Private sector participation is key to the success of ECDs in developing business and 
creating employment. However, it currently remains limited in cross-border activities in CAREC 
due to information asymmetry, weak incentives and insufficient conditions for investment, poor 
access  to  financing,  and  lack  of  effective  dialogue  with  public  sector  stakeholders.  These 
constraints must be eased to improve the environment for cross-border investment among 
Shymkent−Tashkent−Khujand cities and surrounding oblasts.  
 
8.  While ECD is gaining increased interest in the CAREC region, it is a relatively new 
development concept. Wider diffusion to the various communities and societies will help their 
understanding of the connections between ECD and growth, particularly the core concepts and 
key conditions for economic planning and development under a regional context. Thus, enhanced 
knowledge sharing on ECD-related experiences, including with DMCs under other subregional 
                                                
city of Uzbekistan, and is geographically under the Tashkent Oblast; Khujand is both administratively and 
geographically under the Sughd Oblast of Tajikistan. 
7  ADB staff estimation. 
8  United Nations Conference on Trade and Development. Country Profile.  
   http://unctadstat.unctad.org/CountryProfile/en-GB/index.html.

3 
 
programs, will help increase awareness and knowledge of ECD in the CAREC region in a 
coordinated manner. 
 
9.   This TA is designed to support scoping and prefeasibility studies to explore the ECD 
potentials of Shymkent−Tashkent−Khujand cities and surrounding Turkestan−Tashkent−Sughd 
oblasts. The TA will support spatial economic development including trade analysis among the 
three  cities  and  oblasts  to  identify  possible  economic  complementarities,  including  (i) 
agglomeration of certain economic activities, (ii) scale economies in focus sectors and/or areas 
and products, (iii) integration of manufacturing value chains, and (iv) economic and industrial 
cluster development for specialized products. It will identify major constraints, gaps, and weak 
links—in  terms  of  physical  infrastructure  connectivity  (e.g.,  information  and  communication 
technology constraints) and policy environment (e.g., for private sector investment), including 
investment needed—in fully exploiting economic complementarities through an envisaged ECD. 
The TA will also support workshops and seminars that promote ECD-related knowledge sharing 
and awareness raising to enhance understanding and knowledge of ECD in the CAREC region. 
As ECD has great potential in creating job opportunities for women by participating in cross-border 
activities (e.g., tourism and trade), the above-mentioned studies will attend to gender equality as 
a crosscutting issue in the ECD analysis. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: RCI in the CAREC region strengthened.9 The 
TA will have the following outcome: ECD prospects among Shymkent−Tashkent−Khujand cities 
and surrounding oblasts better informed.10  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
11.  Output  1:  Prospects  and  potentials  of  increased  trade  integration  among 
Shymkent−Tashkent−Khujand cities and surrounding Turkestan−Tashkent−Sughd oblasts 
analyzed. The TA will support a scoping study on trade analysis among the three cities and 
surrounding oblasts (including Shymkent–Tashkent, with surrounding Turkestan and Tashkent 
oblasts, and Tashkent−Khujand, with surrounding Tashkent and Sughd oblasts). The TA will focus 
on major goods and services trade and identify (i) complementarities and competitiveness of 
sectors and/or areas and products to fully exploit trade potentials and (ii) major constraints, gaps, 
and weak links in terms of optimal physical infrastructure connectivity and policy environment to 
facilitate trade integration. The study will include policy recommendations and investment needs 
to leverage complementarities to better integrate economic activities for increased trade. 
 
12.  Output 2:  Prospects and potentials of an envisaged Shymkent−Tashkent−Khujand 
tripartite  economic  corridor  development  with  possible  expansion  to  surrounding 
Turkestan−Tashkent−Sughd oblasts analyzed. The TA will support a prefeasibility study to 
assess  the  potential  of  Shymkent−Tashkent−Khujand  tripartite  ECD, with  expansion  to  the 
surrounding Turkestan−Tashkent−Sughd oblasts. Building on the results of output 1, the TA team, 
through the study, will analyze economic interactions and trade links among the three cities and 
surrounding oblasts including between two pairs of cities and oblasts (Shymkent−Tashkent, with 
                                                
9  ADB. 2017. CAREC 2030: Connecting the Region for Shared and Sustainable Development. Manila. 
10  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
 
Turkestan and Tashkent oblasts, and Tashkent−Khujand, with Tashkent and Sughd oblasts). The 
TA will identify possible sectors and/or areas and products to be synergized, and measures to 
enhance complementarities for better integration of economic activities. The TA will also identify 
major constraints, gaps, weak links, and investments needed. Policy recommendations will 
discuss appropriate ECD modalities that fit the development context of the three cities and 
surrounding oblasts, and an institutional framework with roles and responsibilities of different 
players and stakeholders. The TA will assess possible linkage with the ABEC and agricultural 
activities in the Fergana Valley to create wider economic benefits in Central Asia. The TA may 
also explore the potentials of additional ECDs, depending on the progress of the study and based 
on requests from other CAREC DMCs. 
 
13.  Output 3: Economic corridor development related knowledge sharing strengthened 
and  awareness  raised.  The  TA  will  support  workshops,  conferences,  and  stakeholder 
consultations on ECD-related knowledge sharing and awareness raising in the CAREC member 
countries. Views and comments will be solicited from governments and other stakeholders of the 
three target countries and the CAREC community, including private sector practitioners, on ECD 
prospects and benefits in the CAREC region, to facilitate sound understanding of appropriate 
approaches for developing ECD. 
 
C.   Cost and Financing  
  
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $800,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
People’s Republic of China Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund, and administered 
by ADB.11  The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will administer the TA. The Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination 
Division of the Central and West Asia Department (CWRC) will implement the TA by working 
closely  with  the  Central  and  West  Asia  Department  sector  divisions;  resident  missions  in 
Kazakhstan,  Uzbekistan,  and  Tajikistan;  and  other  related  operations  and  knowledge 
departments  (e.g.,  the  East  Asia  Department  and  the  Economic  Research  and  Regional 
Cooperation Department). CWRC will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants; organize 
workshops and conferences; and monitor the TA implementation in coordination with CAREC 
consultants  based  in  Kazakhstan,  Uzbekistan,  and  Tajikistan.  It  will  also  collaborate  with 
international  development  partners  such  as  the  United  Nations  Industrial  Development 
Organization and the World Trade Organization in carrying out selected activities under the TA.  
 
16.  The TA will be implemented over 26 months, from October 2018 to December 2020. ADB 
will engage about 29 person-months of international and 66 person-months of national consulting 
services during the TA implementation period. International consultants will include (i) ECD 
experts, including a team leader, to provide technical advice, analytical support, and policy 
recommendations on the ECD potentials of Shymkent−Tashkent−Khujand cities and surrounding 
Turkestan−Tashkent−Sughd oblasts, and (ii) a trade expert to analyze trade links among the three 
cities  and  surrounding  oblasts  and  provide  policy  recommendations  for  increased  trade 
integration through possible ECD. National consultants based at ADB headquarters and in the 
three CAREC member countries will include (i) four research assistants to provide technical 
support and inputs, including field and local support, to the international consultants and the 
                                                
11 The fund was originally named “People’s Republic of China Regional Cooperation and Poverty Reduction Fund” in 
the 2005 Board paper.

5 
 
CAREC Unit within CWRC; and (ii) a project coordinator to provide operations and administrative 
support to the international consultants and the CAREC Unit. ADB will also engage international 
and national resource persons to provide inputs, review reports, and participate as presenters, 
facilitators, and/or discussants in related meetings and workshops.12  
 
17.  ADB will recruit consultants as individuals and not through a firm since (i) prospective 
consultants will perform activities in three different countries with different development contexts, 
and (ii) the specific expertise and experience required—for example, a wide range of economic 
and sector policy experience, operational experience, and specific knowledge of the CAREC 
Program and Central Asia countries—are unlikely available in a firm. The CAREC Unit will 
manage all individual consultants. 
 
18.  The TA consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Policy (2017, 
as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff 
instructions. The TA funds will be disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
19.  The  CAREC  Unit  will  prepare  TA-related  events  and  materials  and  disseminate 
publications through the ADB and CAREC website, and high-level CAREC sessions in related 
regional forums and events. The CAREC Unit will also conduct internal dissemination of TA- 
related publications jointly with the RCI Thematic Group.  
 
20.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development Bank administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 
to be financed on a grant basis by the People’s Republic of China Poverty Reduction and Regional 
Cooperation Fund for Assessing Economic Corridor Development Potential Among Kazakhstan, 
Uzbekistan, and Tajikistan.
                                                
12 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

  Key Activities with Milestones 
 
1. Prospects and potentials of increased trade integration among Shymkent−Tashkent−Khujand 
cities and surrounding Turkestan−Tashkent−Sughd oblasts analyzed 
 
1.1 Prepare scoping study on trade analysis among the three cities and oblasts (including Shymkent–
Tashkent, with Turkestan and Tashkent oblasts, and Tashkent–Khujand, with Tashkent–Sughd 
oblasts) with focus on major goods and services trade (October 2018−December 2020) 
1.2 Collate and review existing trade data (goods and services) from national statistics, sector-related 
authorities of the three countries and international sources such as WTO and other UN 
organizations (October–December 2018) 
1.3 Consult with the government officials and other stakeholders of Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, and 
Tajikistan on trade in focus sectors and/or areas and products and ECD-related issues (October–
December 2018) 
1.4 Organize workshops to solicit comments and views from the three governments and other 
stakeholders on the draft scoping study (January−April 2020) 
1.5 Finalize and publish scoping study (May−December 2020) 
 
2. Prospects and potentials of an envisaged Shymkent−Tashkent−Khujand tripartite ECD with 
possible expansion to surrounding Turkestan−Tashkent−Sughd oblasts analyzed 
 
2.1 Prepare prefeasibility study on ECD potentials among the three cities and surrounding oblasts 
(October 2018−December 2020) 
2.2 Collate and review existing literature on ECD, including best ECD practices from other regions 
and/or subregions, and existing economic data (e.g., cross-border trade, health services, transport, 
and tourism) from national statistics, sector-related authorities of the three countries, and 
international sources such as WTO and other UN organizations (October–December 2018) 
2.3 Consult with government officials and other stakeholders of Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, and 
Tajikistan (October–December 2018) 
2.4 Organize workshops to solicit comments and views from three governments and other 
stakeholders on the draft prefeasibility study (January−April 2020) 
2.5 Finalize and publish prefeasibility study (May−December 2020) 
 
3. ECD related knowledge sharing strengthened and awareness raised 
 
3.1  Identify relevant ECD themes and sectors and/or areas for development of knowledge sharing  
       and/or ECD awareness-raising events (October 2018–December 2019) 
3.2 Prepare and/or organize ECD knowledge sharing and awareness-raising events, including   
      dissemination of publications (January 2019–December 2020) 
Inputs 
People’s Republic of China Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund: $800,000  
Assumptions for Partner Financing 
Not applicable. 
CAREC = Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation, DMC = developing member country, ECD = economic corridor 
development, TA = technical assistance, UN = United Nations, WTO = World Trade Organization. 
a ADB. 2017. CAREC 2030: Connecting the Region for Shared and Sustainable Development. Manila. 
Source: Asian Development Bank.
